item.title: XenoGov
item.description:
of 2The inaugural project of our speculative start-up aims to tokenize and auction the United Statesof America through a blockchain-implemented constitution. We’ve selected the American constitution asour prototype for several compelling reasons. Firstly, its concise and straightforward nature makes it idealfor blockchain implementation, especially from an originalist perspective that focuses on the fundamentalrelationships between branches of government. Secondly, the profound emotional and cultural investmentAmericans have in their constitution provides an excellent foundation for a provocative public auctionand communication strategy. This is evidenced by events like constitutionDAO, which raised over $60million in cryptocurrency to bid on an original copy of the Constitution, demonstrating the potentialfor significant public engagement with our project. Lastly, as the oldest democratic constitution craftedby and for the people, the U.S. Constitution represents a perfect subject for our artistic exploration. Ourproject simultaneously pays homage to this democratic legacy while interrogating the commodificationof governance in the digital age. By tokenizing the implementation of this foundational document, weaim to spark dialogue about the intersection of historical democratic principles, blockchain technology,and the future of governance, all within the framework of contemporary conceptual art.The implementation of a blockchain-based constitution using Solidity leverages an advancedarchitecture combining the Diamond pattern and nested proxy contracts, with additional facetsrepresenting the various branches of government. At its core, the “DiamondConstitution” contract actsas the central hub, utilizing the Diamond pattern for flexibility and upgradeability. This main contractdelegates calls to multiple facets, each representing different constitutional elements or governmentalbranches. For instance, we create separate facets for the Executive, Legislative, and Judicial branches. TheLegislative facet could further be divided into sub-facets for the House of Representatives and the Senate,each with its own internal organization and voting mechanisms.u2p050 proposes to create a speculative start-up, named XenoGov, that aims to sell digital statesto existing States by implementing Constitutions as smart contracts on the blockchain. Recognizing thatcurrent political climates may not be ready for blockchain-based governance, the company positionsitself as a conceptual art project that is fully functional but not yet commercially viable. This approachallows the start-up to exist in a liminal space between art and technology, pushing the boundaries ofwhat a start-up can be by auctioning conceptual projects and creating a speculative market for ideas thatsociety isn’t prepared to accept as practical products. Conceptually, it asserts that any political regimecan be implemented as computable functions on a blockchain, allowing for multiple, even ideologicallyopposed, state systems to coexist on the same platform. The long-term strategy employs the concept ofthe Overton window—the range of ideas acceptable in public discourse—to gradually shift perceptions.By initially operating as an art-focused enterprise, the company lays groundwork for potential futuretransformation into a real-world provider of blockchain-based governance solutions, should politicalattitudes evolve to embrace such technologies.THE SPECULATIVE START-UPXe n o G o vUSA’S CONSTITUTION AS A COMMODITYTECHNICAL DETAILS OF FEASABILITYu2p050Our key assertion is that any administrative system defined in a constitution can be implementedas a set of computable functions on a Turing machine, and by extension, on a Turing-complete blockchain.This principle applies universally, regardless of the political ideology or structural complexity of the systemin question. The profound implication is that a single Turing-complete blockchain can simultaneouslyhost multiple, even ideologically opposed, state systems. For instance, it could run both the People'sRepublic of China's Constitution and the United States Constitution concurrently, each operating as anindependent set of smart contracts within the same blockchain environment. This capability stems fromthe blockchain's nature as a universal computational substrate, capable of executing any computablefunction. By encoding constitutional provisions, administrative procedures, and governance mechanismsas smart contracts, we create digital parallels of entire state systems. This simultaneous implementationof diverse governance models on a unified blockchain platform not only demonstrates the universalcomputability of administrative systems but also opens up unprecedented possibilities for comparativegovernance studies, political experimentation, and the creation of parallel, non-geographically boundstate entities in the digital realm.We want to situate this project within the rich tradition of legal art and institutional critique,drawing significant parallels to seminal works in art history. Like Yves Klein's "Zones of ImmaterialPictorial Sensibility" and Tino Sehgal's oral art transactions, it challenges conventional notions ofownership, value, and documentation in art. By implementing constitutional systems on a blockchain, itechoes the conceptual approach of artists like Hans Haacke, whose "MoMA Poll" questioned institutionalpower structures. The project's focus on smart contracts as a medium for governance resonates with theevolving concept of "contract art", exemplified by the Projansky contract and its adaptations by artistslike Cady Noland. Moreover, in its exploration of administrative systems as computable functions, thework engages with themes of authorship and originality similar to Kenneth Goldsmith's appropriationart, while pushing the boundaries of what constitutes a legal artwork. By merging blockchain technologywith constitutional law, this project not only continues the legacy of institutional critique but also expandsthe definition of legal art into the digital realm, creating a new form of conceptual artwork that exists atthe intersection of law, technology, and governance.The Executive facet might include functions for presidential powers and cabinet operations,while the Judicial facet could handle case management and judicial review processes. Amendments areimplemented through a system of nested proxy contracts, allowing for a hierarchical structure of lawswhere newer amendments can modify or override older ones. This approach mirrors the real-worldconstitutional amendment process. Access controls ensure that only authorized entities can proposeand ratify amendments or execute branch-specific functions. For example, only addresses registered asRepresentatives could participate in House votes within the Legislative facet. By combining the Diamondpattern, branch-specific facets, and nested proxies, we create a highly flexible, upgradeable, and realisticsystem. This structure accurately represents the complex, layered nature of a constitutional government,complete with checks and balances, while harnessing the immutability and transparency of blockchaintechnology.CONCEPTUAL FRAMEWORKRELATION TO ART HISTORY09.25.2024 - AUBERVILLIERS, FRANCEu2p050@gmail.com
XenoGov_u2p050.pdf

item.title: DocuFiction
item.description: By dint of putting our hands in the machines, we have realized that they oblige us, out of circumstances, to push the limits of the conceptual framework in which our thinking unfolds: organic vs. inorganic, thinkable vs. unthinkable, identities vs. differences, human vs. non-human, alive vs. inert … Machines inhabit our collective imagination in an ambivalent way, both as instruments of unlimited submission and as essential levers of emancipation in a world in the throes of collapse. This is what interests us. In our essay film, we want to show the computational machine in all its equivocity. By showing clearly that this takes us a further step towards a new cosmology, where humans are no longer at the center.detail-docu-768x432.png

item.title: Pornotopie
item.description:
PORNOTOPIEOn est allé voir une expo d’art porno générée par une intelligence artificiellePhotography is traditionally the notation of light, light that traces and leaves traces. We worked with algorithms to reverse the terms of the word “photograph”. We desired a notation that expresses itself in the light.So, in this series of photo-graphs, it is no longer an eye that produces a mechanical cut in the world, but a computer eye that expresses what the computer can witness from the streams of pornographic videos. It turns out to be a bizarre environment where the rigid organization between the organs no longer remains, nor the clear separation between genders.From a binary language composed only of an alternation between 0 and 1, we notice the specter of a non-binary world, a continuous plane of exchange between bodies. But, to go further, we could say that a machinic sexuality emerges, since there is a replication of the same with a difference: the images are produced by images within the machine itself. It is therefore a sexuality of symbols expressed by images that appear there. A symbolic nude.of 6PORN-O-TOPIEUne aventure média-porno-archéologiqueEn m’asseyant dans la cabine individuelle de visionnage du magasin spécialisé LoveShop, j’avais la sensation de faire un saut dans un passé que je n’avais jamais fréquenté.Après avoir marché dans le couloir rempli de DVDs et de cassettes de filmspornographiques des années 80-90 et un court aperçu des produits dérivés de 50 Shades ofGrey — dont Love Shop possède la diffusion exclusive sur le territoire français — j’aipénétré dans l’espace réservé aux cabines. J’étais loin de me sentir dans un cadre familierde consommation de films pornographiques. Ma génération est plutôt habituée à un cadreintime, souvent une chambre personnelle avec un ordinateur connecté à l’ADSL et uneproposition invasive de contenus dès l’entrée sur un hébergeur en ligne.La cabine fait 3 mètres carrés. L’odeur n’est pas celle d’une maison et pourtant on yest pour regarder la même chose qu’allongé sur son lit avec un ordinateur. Seulement ledécor est celui d’un autre âge, celui d’une autre époque. Le distributeur à kleenex en haut àgauche affiche encore un prix en francs. Après avoir composé le code me permettantd'accéder à l'œuvre, plusieurs questions m’assaillent. J’ai essayé de me demandercomment les gens avaient pu réagir lors de l’ouverture de ce sex-shop. Peut-être que lescabines à une certaine époque étaient le tout dernier cri en matière d’offre de sex-shop. Estce qu’il y avait déjà eu des avant-premières de films pornographiques dans ces cabines ?Ou encore des œuvres d’art dans des cabines ? Toutes ces réflexions venant au fil duvisionnage de la vidéo font naître la question suivante en moi : est ce que PORN-O-TOPIEne serait pas une machine à voyager dans le temps ?La proposition d’u2p050 est un canal ouvert vers ces passésmédiatico-pornographiques qui semblent se compresser au fil de l’obsolescence desmoyens de captation et de diffusion. Dans son article publié en 1996, « Time Traveling in theGallery: An Archeological Approach in Media Art »1, le théoricien des médias finlandais ErkkiHuhtamo nous invitait à considérer des travaux artistiques comme des machines à voyagerdans le temps, des machines nous permettant de naviguer entre des couches du passé etdu présent de nos média. PORN-O-TOPIE semble répondre à cet appel en nous ouvrantdes connexions avec nos passés pornographiques et à leurs agendas médiatiques.La cabine est l’élément déclencheur de cette sensation trouble de voyage dans lepassé - le premier arrêt du voyage de la capsule temporelle PORN-O-TOPIE dans laquellej’ai embarqué.I. Archéologie de la cabine« Au fond de la salle, un peu à l’écart et moyennant un supplément, certainsexemplaires présentaient des bobineaux réservés aux seuls messieurs, où l’onpouvait apprécier des dames qui enlèvent leur robe et osent se présenter, suprême1 HUHTAMO, Erik, « Time Traveling in the Gallery: An Archeological Approach in Media Art », dansMary Anne Moser et Douglas MacLeod (dir.), Immersed in Technology: Art and Virtual Environments,Cambridge (MA), The MIT Press, 1996, p.232-268.audace à l’époque, en collant et maillot ! Tous les autres bobineaux étaient des filmsvisibles par un public familial »2.À la fin du XIXe siècle, les premiers appareillages techniques permettant de donnerl’illusion d’une image animée voient le jour. Entre 1890 et 1900, les frères Lumière et lacompagnie de Thomas Edison développent leurs prototypes et déposent de nombreuxbrevets. La citation ci-dessus est un extrait de l’ouvrage Grammaire du Cinéma (2010 publiépar les historiens du cinéma Marie-France Briselance et Jean-Claude Morin concernantl’utilisation de la machine et sa réception culturelle à ses débuts. On retrouve notre fameusecabine. Il est étonnant qu’on retrouve la trace du décor de PORN-O-TOPIE dès l’émergencedes premiers appareils pré-cinématographiques. Le kinétoscope est considéré comme leplus ancien dispositif technique permettant de donner l'illusion de mouvement d’imagesphotographiques. C’est une sorte de boîte d’un mètre et demi de hauteur, où, via unœilleton, un observateur unique pouvait voir défiler en boucle les images d’un film depellicule de 17 mètres de long, à 48 images par seconde.Page d’Illustration de l’article Le Kinétoscope d'Edison de Gaston Tissandier, publié dans LaNature: Revue des sciences et de leurs applications aux arts et à l'industrie, Octobre 1894:Vingt-deuxième année, deuxième semestre, p. 325–326.Cet essor des appareils pour animer l’image s’inscrivent dans un contexte cultureloccidental de recherche de vitesse et de divertissement, comme le rappelle Thomas Gunninà travers son concept de l’esthétique de l’attraction :« L’expérience vertigineuse de la fragilité de notre connaissance dumonde d’avant le pouvoir de l’illusion visuelle a produit ce mélange de plaisiret d’anxiété que les fournisseurs d’arts populaires ont appelé les “sensationset frissons”, et sur lequel ils ont fondé une nouvelle esthétique de l’attraction.Le train en marche des frères Lumière n’a pas produit simplementl’expérience négative de la peur, mais aussi la forme de divertissement2 Jean-Claude, Morin & Marie-France, Briselance, Grammaire du cinéma, Nouveau Monde, 2010, p.26
Texte_PORN-O-TOPIE_Une-aventure-média-porno-archéologique.pdfJaquetteVHS.pngporn_O-topie-1.jpgpornO-topie-8-1024x1024.jpg

item.title: Protozoa
item.description: Nuit Blanche au 6b : Protozoa - YouTubeThe polymorphous company Soñal Sinor and the digital production studio U2P050 jointly produce a project mixing current dance (krump, freestyle, hip-hop, flamenco …), electronic music and artificial intelligence to produce a series of six dance films in which the recorded bodies become the main material. Without domination, it is a process of experimentation which, thanks to randomness and indeterminacy, seeks to introduce a transversality of sensitivities, materials and organic / machinic mediums of expression.

item.title: Moebia
item.description: MOEBIAMoebia is a book that tells the story of a small group of living forms landing on a desolated land full of these goddamn scorpions. The technique used to produce this book is the text to pic. An accelerated review of a sum of image’s collections. A gathering of collective memories to shape an imaginary world haunted data set dreaming of moebius ghosts.Produced in collaboration with Jeanne Knoplioch, Zoey, Philippe Ngo and Pauline Broquet.Capture d’écran 2022-08-30 à 22.23.03.pngCapture d’écran 2022-08-29 à 21.03.13.jpgVue du livre 3-modified.jpg
